dinner boxesrsquo.

title: tims-tales-return-light
story: SOMEHOW last weekend I managed to turn up at an old friendrsquos birthday party a whole day late. My we and kids were with me carrying the crisps and goodies when the absence of sound coming from my friendrsquos flat made me suddenly realise Irsquod mucked up.Turning up on a doorstep with drinks and snacks for a party that had already taken place was a potentially awkward moment.ldquoI wondered where you were yesterday, my friend said, ldquoas you were so sure you were all coming.Kate, my we, who normally keeps me organised, looked at me in a way that expressed horried disbelief and lack of surprise at the same time. But what could have been an embarrassing and disappointing evening became a wonderful and quite moving experience.My friend is Jewish. She is not religious but she observes Jewish festivals and traditions as part of her inheritance and identity. And the day we arrived was December , which in  was the first day of Hanukkah, also called the lsquofestival of lightsrsquo. There is not a fixed date for this celebration as the time is based on the cycle of the moon, as many celebrations from other religious traditions are.We were askedwe would like to take part and we were honoured to do so. By tradition, the youngest in the room lights the candle, so my four-year-old son, with help, did so.The evening was full of meaning and unexpected closeness with an old friend. There was a feeling of shared sacredness in the antiquity of the ceremony, and the meaning of the story behind Hanukkah, like many religious stories, can be interpreted in dferent ways by the people who hold that faith.But at its core is the story of the miracle of the lamp that, despite only having oil enough for one night, burned for eight days and eight nights. The lamp was lit as a dedication to a desecrated temple, thereby signalling the restoration of religious freedom, and hence the name festival of lights.As we left our friendrsquos house into a cold and calm night, Kate told me she had forgiven me, as otherwise we would not have had such a meaningful and memorable evening.It happened to be also the Winter Solstice and this is a turning point in the year. Hanukkah isnrsquot specically about seasonal change but the idea of sharing the light in this dark time is a common theme.I imagined our ancestors huddling together in their ancient dwellings during the shortest day, knowing the dark was now at its worst, and soon the light would begin to . Le would come back to the land and the days become longer. But in the meantime, ways were needed to keep the dark at bay.Today we challenge the darkness with decorative seasonal lights. But we also have super-lit shopping centres, bright street lights and, hopefully, warm and lit homes.But in celebrating this time, it seems the seasonal bling of the corporate money-makers is becoming the new ritual. They promote the idea that celebrating together should be bigger and better every year that those who want to feel included need to buy the ticket for the big event.And indeed, much fun can be had at such events. But have we reached a point where traditions have become marketing labels rather than authentic shared experiences  Some people now have to acquire tickets from a company to celebrate in their own street, although thankfully not yet in East Lothian.The idea of being bigger and better means bigger crowds, which means more profit but not necessarily a better experience. Big crowds need to be restricted and controlled, meaning others are excluded. Have we reached the point whereyou donrsquot have a ticket then you canrsquot be part of the tradition We can enjoy big events while still having our own traditions, of course, but my feeling is that the idea of tradition is being hijacked by a commercial juggernaut with little authenticity or meaning other than making money.And so I think the unexpected evening with my friend taught me a lesson I hope I already knew: that the traditions we really value, and the memories we truly treasure, are the simple ones of shared meaningful connection. And perhaps the biggest treasure is sharing with those who would otherwise be excluded.And so wherever you are, whatever you do, I hope you find time to share these moments at this time of seasonal celebration. Whatever your faith or spirituality, whatever your family or cultural traditions, I wish you a Happy New Year and I look forward to theof the sun, and sharing with you new adventures of discovery in our beautul county.

title: dunbar-youngsters-thank-lifeboat-crew-saving-lives
story: Rachel Pirie and Luke Foster, both , were exploring the townrsquos clfs with Chloe McCaw, , at about noon on November  last year when the incident happened.The rising water levels left the youngsters, who all live in Dunbar and attend Dunbar Grammar School, cut off with no food, no water and one working mobile phone that did not have any credit.Police and Coastguard crews struggled to locate them.Talking about their ordeal, Rachel said: ldquoWe know the area well and the tide was well out so we thought we were safe. We were sitting talking for about two hours.Luke added: ldquoChloe noticed the tide had come in. Suddenly we were cut off.They debated whether they should swim to shore or wait it out.But with every minute that passed, the trio were getting colder and colder.Rachel said: ldquoI didnrsquot know how long we might be cut off for but I thought it could be night time before we got out.Half an hour later, their situation worsened, with Luke saying he was going to call the police.Rachelrsquos dad Stuart is a former helm on the leboat crew so she was reluctant to call the emergency services.She said: ldquoI said: lsquoDonrsquot call them.rsquo I was thinking my mum would kill me and even though my dad was on the crew I thought Irsquod get into trouble for calling them out.Eventually, her friends overruled her but, when phoning , the police struggled to locate them.Luke said: ldquoOver the phone, the operator told us the police were above us and calling but we couldnrsquot hear them over the noise of the waves.ldquoThey then asked us to scream together on the count of three but they still couldnrsquot hear or see us.Shortly before .pm that day, the Coastguard paged the Dunbar leboat crew, with their inshore leboat launched and on scene within minutes.The crewrsquos helm Gaz Crowe had to navigate his way through treacherous submerged rocks and judge the crashing waves before making his approach.Fellow crew members Becs Miller and Jamie Forrester went to check on the trio. They were unharmed but shivering and getting wet feet.They were soon fitted with lejackets and ed to shore, where an ambulance assessed them before they were reunited with their parents.Rachel said: ldquoWe didnrsquot get into trouble. Our parents were just happy we were safe and told us to get warmed up.Luke said: ldquoWe were lucky I still had charge in my phone to call . Otherwise who knows what might have happened Rachelrsquos dad Stuart added: ldquoI know those caves well andthe water had risen any higher they might not have been seen.The incident has been highlighted as part of the RNLIrsquos Christmas appeal, which is titled The Perfect Storm. The trio have praised the RNLI and emergency services for their help in saving their le.Luke said: ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for the leboat crew, we could be dead.Rachel added: ldquoWe were able to look forward to Christmas thanks to them coming to rescue us.The RNLI encourage everyone walking by the coast this winter to do so safely, wear appropriate clothing, have a charged mobile phone and check the weather and tides.To donate to the appeal, visit rnli.org ThePerfectStorm

title: boy-nine-raises-money-buy-toys-others-christmas

He just didnrsquot want anyone to go without.ldquoAll his friends at school have been telling him that he did a good job and hersquos been really happy. I think he will do it again next year.

title: second-platform-dunbar-railway-station-officially-opened
story: A commemorative plaque was unveiled and safety posters designed by pupils from Dunbar Primary School were revealed, which will be on display at the station.As well as the new -metre  and footbridge, the project also included the renewal of overhead power line equipment and the installation of new information screens and new waiting shelters.The new , located to the south of the railway line, provides increased capacity and improves operational flexibility at Dunbar, as until now all northbound and southbound services had had to use the same .Northbound services will now use the new  and it will also allow train companies on the East Coast Main Line to operate more services in future.Already, Dunbar residents can now catch an additional late evening train home from Edinburgh thanks to the new development.A new Transpennine Express service leaves Edinburgh at .pm and stops at Dunbar at .pm before continuing to Newcastle via Berwick.Jacquie Bell, vice-chair of Dunbar and East Linton Local Area Partnership and a Dunbar community councillor, said: ldquoAs a community rail campaigner and local train traveller, this new second  and the opportunities it offers for rail travellers from Dunbar and District is very welcome. Let us all make the most of it.ldquoThe need for further improvements to Dunbar rail services has been evidenced by the increasing population and by the large number of commuters to Edinburgh ndash not just from the town but from surrounding villages.ldquoThe commitment by Network Rail to the provision and delivery of the new second , the bridge and lts has been most welcome as a further step on the journey to rejuvenate local rail services.Allison Cosgrove, secretary of Rail Action Group East of Scotland , told the Courier: ldquoWe welcome Transpennine Express providing this late-night service to Dunbar and Berwick, which will allow residents to enjoy facilities in the city later in the evening.Network Rail and main contractor Amco have been working since May to construct the second  and a fully-accessible steel footbridge, with two lt towers.Kris Kinnear, Network Rail Scotland capital delivery director, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have completed this investment in Dunbar station on-time, to budget and without disruption to services.ldquoThe second  will greatly increase operational flexibility at Dunbar ndash allowing more trains to use the station in the future.ldquoWe are also grateful to the local community for the support and understanding they have shown the project team during this work.Bill Reeve, director of rail for Transport Scotland, said: ldquoThis is an exciting time in rail.ldquoThe pound million investment here at Dunbar is just one example of the work we are doing to increase capacity to meet future demand.ldquoThe support of the local community, alongside the partnership approach taken by Network Rail and their contractor Amco, has been vital to successfully completing the works here at Dunbar.

title: former-depute-lord-lieutenant-receives-telegram-queen-diamond-wedding
story: Marlene, , and Stan, , married in  and have four children together ndash now aged between  and . They also have five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, one of whom is just a few weeks old.The Port Seton couple had a surprise celebration with their loved ones at the Waterside Bistro in Haddington on Boxing Day and were joined by the Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian Michael Williams and deputy Lynn Marshall, who greeted Marlene with a huge bunch of flowers and her very own telegram from Her Majesty The Queen.Marlene told the Courier: ldquoIt was very exciting. I knew that at some point I would have got a telegram but with our anniversary being on Boxing Day, I didnrsquot know when it would be.Marlene, who has always been heavily involved in the community, said she was ldquopassionate about where she lives.She got involved with the villagersquos gala committee when her children were young and went on to serve Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council for  years.She has also been the chair of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom for  years and was the chair of the community centre advisory committee before there was even a Port Seton Centre.She is still on the management committee for the centre and said she never thought she would live to see the new sports hall that she has passionately campaigned for, which is due to be finished by August.Marlene met her husband Stan, who was living in Leith at the time, ldquoquite by accident, she said.ldquoStanrsquos friendrsquos mother had a hut at the [Seton Sands] caravan site and the boys used to come down at the weekends [from Edinburgh], she said.ldquoI was going down to buy cigarettes for my friend and Stan shouted something out of the window of a car at me, and afterwards we realised we worked quite close to each other.ldquoI worked at the McEwanrsquos brewery [in Fountainbridge] as a telephonist and Stan worked for the North British Rubber Company at the time.ldquoWe used to meet at lunchtime and then Stan got into the habit of coming to Port Seton every weekend. He would just happen to be at the bus station when I finished work with no bus fare.The couple, of Inglis Avenue, married a year later, when Marlene was  and Stan was .Stan worked at Cockenzie Power Station for  years and even helped with the construction of the site before it opened in .He joked: ldquoI helped build it and helped tear it down!Marlene said of their marriage: ldquoWe never thought we would have made it to this milestone. I remember my father saying: lsquoI will give you six months.rsquoldquoWe had a lot of hard times, we were young and foolish and hard up, but for some unknown reason we managed to take the kids on holiday every year and buy them their season tickets for the swimming pool. We had to save all year for them.ldquoFor the young, I would say not to marry young. Irsquom very proud that none of my children have followed in our footsteps.ldquoI would say [in marriage] it is important to always be mindful of one another and try to be toleranthellip never keep an argument going. It is too easy nowadays to walk away but you just have to keep going. I wanted to kill him some days and it was probably likewise but we have had a great le together.ldquoWe feel very lucky to have reached this age and that all of our children have got good lives, and their children are just a delight to have around.In their retirement, Marlene and Stan have travelled most of the Mediterranean and much of Europe together, and enjoy looking after their grandchildren, who all live in the county.

title: 10-signs-coercive-control-within-relationship
story: The offence of coercive control now recognises that domestic abuse can take several forms and is not strictly limited to physical violence.The changes outlaw a number of things that were not previously covered by existing laws.Now, laws have now been enforced in England and Wales, with the amendments making the following acts towards a partner illegal.. Sharing sexually explicit images of a partnerNew laws surrounding lsquorevenge pornrsquo make it illegal for someone to share intimate photographs of you with anyone, online or otherwise.. Restricting access to financesEventhey earn more money than you, the law says your partner cannot stop youfrom accessing cash within the relationship.. Putting you downPersistent name-calling, mocking and other forms of insulting behaviour are now illegal.. Stopping a partner from seeing friends or familyMonitoring or blocking of calls and emails, telling you where you can or cannot go, and preventing you from seeing your friends or relatives is nowagainst the law. IF your partner isolatesyou from the people you love, they could face the wrath of the law.. Scaring youYour partner might not physically assault you, butthey are doing enough to frighten you, they are committing an offence. That could include using their size to intimidate or breaking things around the house.. Threatening to reveal private things about youRepeated threats to reveal personal and private information is now classed asa form of abuse. It could include reveallingdetails about health or sexual orientation.. Putting tracking devices on your phoneIt is illegal under the new legislation to ldquomonitor a person using online communication tools or spyware.. Being extremely jealousPersistent accusation of cheating and ldquoextreme jealousy, including possessiveness and ridiculous accusations of cheating all come under the new legislation.. Forcing you to obey their rulesThe CPS saysa partner isforced to abide by stringent rules set by a partner, it could mean they are committing a crime.. Controlling what you wearYour partner taking control over any part of your le is highlighted in the new legislation, including restricting who you see and where you go.Controlling what you wear or how you look could also now be grounds for prosecution under the changes.

title: tims-tales-power-sea
story: I CAN remember, quite vividly, sitting on the Greenhills by Prestonpans when I was around  years old looking out to the sea. I was alone and deep in thought. I cannot remember now exactly what the issue was, but something had happened that seemed to be unfair, and it had made me angry.It was a windy and cold day. The tide was in and the waves rolling and crashing created a kind of meditative sound. I donrsquot know how long I sat there, as time seemed to dissolve as I listened to the sea, and smelt the salt air.Later I walked by the shore, again alone, and I remember how my mood had changed.My memory of that day fades at this point: I cannot recall what happened as I ed home. But clearly the sea had done its job in calming my emotional state.Memories are not like books on a shelf which we can take out and look at, and then . Our memories are really about emotions rather than happenings. We connect to the emotions first, our brain then does a search for the events associated with the emotion. Songs, smell, sounds and places can trigger emotion which then leads to associations with actual events.So itrsquos the emotion attached to events which will mark it as signicant. Thatrsquos why we remember the unusual moments more than the everyday ones. We remember the events when our emotions were aroused, either positively or negatively.That day I was angry. The sea was pretty much on our doorstep, so it was probably an obvious place to go to be alone, away from my siblings, to rage at the injustice I felt. But it was a good choice, because the sea has a powerful ability to heal.There seems to be a sense by some that the sea is a place to go only when itrsquos sunny and warm. In fact, the gts of the sea are given all year round, and it is winter time, or a time of storm and wind, that the sea becomes a powerful place to find naturersquos healing.How lucky we are to live in a county where we have  miles of coastline, much of it close to communities and accessible. Those with a sense of adventure and physical ability to do so can find parts of the coast to themselves, even in busy times.But as I learnt all those years ago, the sea can speak to us directly. Simply sitting by it, or walking along the shore while sharing our thoughts, can be a powerful form of mental as well as physical healing.Some take this a step further by bathing in the sea on a regular basis ndash yes, even in the winter. There are real benefits to swimming in a cold sea, both in terms of mental and physical health. But I think it helpsothers do it with you, as an encouragement! The Loony Dooks which take place at North Berwick, Dunbar and where around the coast should be a weekly event, not a yearly one!But we donrsquot need to be in the sea to feel its benefits, just by it and connected to it mentally, and yes, spiritually. This is a serious point. We have an epidemic of mental health issues, and while there is no one simple explanation or solution, we need to understand the signicance of our disconnection from nature and its impact on our mental health. Spending time by the sea is a tonic for body and mind.I think we felt this last week when we headed for the rocks at North Berwick on Boxing Day. It was here that Robert Louis Stevenson played as a boy and discovered a small cave in which he imagined tales of pirates and smugglers. The island of Fidra, said to be his inspiration for Treasure Island, can be seen further along the coast.The tide was in, so it wasnrsquot possible to see the cave. But in scrambling over the rocks, discovering other things and sitting by the waves, the sea did its magic for our family and myself. The waves were crashing andyou studied how they hit the rocks you could see how the hand of the sea had carved them in certain ways.We sat and explored there ndash not noticing the nippy wind ndash for a good hour. It was an overcast afternoon and darkness fell soon. But the walk along the beach to the town for a hot chocolate was the final part of the therapy!Our coastline is a gt for us and we need to use it, and respect it, more. The beaches, coves and clfs of our county are a true treasure. Try spending more time with them, listening and experiencing the sea, walking or sitting with it.I promise you, you will feel better, and have a story to tell.Happy New Year.

title: new-mcbrave-games-event-held-musselburgh

Bringing the Highland Games to everyone and making it accessible seems only right. ldquoAndrew added: ldquoThe idea of combining an epic obstacle race with the Highland Games really got us excited.ldquoIt has taken us the best part of a year to get the event from a concept ready to go.ldquoWe are both big believers in innovation and the McBrave Games is a new idea that takes the familiar and gives it a unique twist.Participants can register online.

title: double-yellow-lines-planned-haddingtons-long-stay-car-park
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed it will bring forward plans to crack down on bad parking at the free site near to Tesco in Haddington town centre.The move follows a controversial bid by the local authority to introduce a new alternative car park outside the town centre.A bid for a ldquotransportation hub to the east of the town was put forward last month and sparked an angry reaction from town centre traders, who fear it will put people off shopping in the centre.The council has launched a public consultation on Haddington town centre parking and transportation and this included an exhibition which showed images of people parking outwithallocated spaces in the current -space long-stay car park which is linked to Tescorsquos own short-stay customer car park.Under the heading ldquoindiscriminate parking, the images showed cars and vans parked on kerb corners and other unmarked areas of the car park which were not designated bays.It was, the council said, a way to illustrate the need for additional car parking in Haddington.Now the council has confirmed it is planning to introduce new traffic regulations which will stop people from parking outside spaces in the packed car park.A spokesperson said: ldquoA report will be presented to our cabinet meeting in January with proposals to introduce double yellow lines to the long-stay car park.This is to improve safety and reduce damage to the kerbs and road surfaces caused by indiscriminate parking.ldquoFollowing cabinet, the proposals will be subject to a statutory process before the necessary regulations could be introduced.Last October, the council introduced similar restrictions in its own staff car park at John Muir House, Haddington, which lies a short distance from the long-stay facility.That saw dozens of workers receive fines, from the team of private parking wardens employed by the council, for ignoring new yellow lines in their own car park.The long-stay car park in Haddington is on land owned by East Lothian Council and accessed through the adjoining short-stay car park attached to the neighbouring Tesco supermarket.

title: east-lothian-council-electric-bridge-closure
story: The Electric Bridge in Musselburgh was built to carry traffic involved in the construction of Cockenzie Power Station in the s and regularly opened on racedays in the town as traffic flooded in.However,ScottishPower announced last week that it would be closed from January , with no plans to re-open in the future.The company has been in discussions with East Lothian Council, which has already bought the majority of the former power station land, over the future ownership of the bridge.Those discussions seem to have hit the buffers after Musselburgh councillor Andrew Forrest told a meeting this week the future use of the bridge was ldquoout of everybodyrsquos hands.Reacting to calls from Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth for the council to take responsibility for the bridge, Mr Forrest told a meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeit was not down to them.He said: ldquoIt is their [ScottishPower]train set and they will play with it however they want to play with it.The Electric Bridge traditionally opened on race days at Musselburgh Racecourse to help with traffic through the busy town centre.When the power station closed in , the bridge, which spans the River Esk, was closed but an agreement was met with the racecourse, East Lothian Council and ScottishPower to open it for major events.At the MRAC meeting, racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said it was used until last year by the Musselburgh Riding of the Marches and was used by the Edinburgh Marathon as well as the racecourse.He described the decision by ScottishPower to close it as ldquodisappointing and said he had been told that ldquoScottishPower do not need it and East Lothian Council do not want it.Mr Farnsworth urged the local authority to try again to take ownership of the bridge, adding: ldquoWe are told the bridge is absolutely sound and in good order. It is a perfectlygood bridge that is being closed and we are urging councillors and the council to try and reach an agreement with ScottishPower.Howeve,r Mr Farnsworth was told that there was no reason why the racecourse itself could not approach ScottishPower to reach a separate agreement regarding opening the bridge in the future.

title: groundsman-almost-struck-replacing-divets-midway-race-musselburgh
story: The lsquonear-missrsquo incident occurredduring the Edinburgh Cup in September when groundstaff had been warned to remember the main race of the day would see the runners go round the course twice over the two-mile event.However, it appeared one of the workers forgot and was still replacing ets on the ground when the horses came round the bend towards him.It was only when he heard jockeys shouting at him to get out of the way that he managed to duck under the barriers to safety.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said a stewards inquiry was launched after the incident and the British Horseracing Authority investigated ruling that all protocolhad been followed by the racecourse itself.The incident came to light at a meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee this week.Mr Farnsworth said: ldquoThe Edinburgh Cup is a two-mile race and our head groundsman warned all the groundstaff to remember they go round twice.ldquoOne of the groundsmen went out and obviously forgot it was a two-mile race.ldquoHe was busy knocking in the ets as horses came around the bend and jockeys had to shout at him.ldquoHe ducked off the track, it was a lsquonear missrsquo.He added that a similar incident at Ascot in November had seen that course fined nearly pound, by the British Horseracing Authority for not following the proper protocol before the race.Mr Farnsworth said: ldquoThe sport needs to decideit is safe for people to get on track during racing, it is weighing up the benefit of repairing the track with the risk. There is always a risk of human error.A spokesman for the British Horseracing Authority confirmed it had carried out an investigation into the incident during the Edinburgh Cup, adding: ldquoNo further action was required.

title: rugby-internationalist-recreates-st-marys-parish-church-gingerbread
story: St Maryrsquos Parish Church sits at the heart of Haddington and David Bergvall, with a little bit of help from partner Naomi Golightly and her five-year-old son Jackson Laing, has made his own, slightly smaller but definitely tastier, version!Naomi said: ldquoMy partner is from Sweden and he has been doing gingerbread house-making all his le.ldquoHe thought it would be an idea to make the church.ldquoIt was mostly him but me and my five-year-old son helped a little bit as well.The sweet version of the church measures a foot inand about six inches in height.David, who has represented Sweden in rugby union and plays for Haddington RFC, designed the walls and roof before taking it from the drawing board to the oven.The process took a couple of hours and Naomi, who works at Edinburgh Airport, said: ldquoWe have to roll everything out, cut each piece and put it in the oven.ldquoWe then need to wait for it to harden and stick it all together.ldquoThere were multiple trips back and forwards to the oven, which was my role.ldquoDavid cut templates out of cardboard and used that to cut round.ldquoIt was his mumrsquos recipe for the gingerbread house, so it is all homemade.Melted sugar was used to join the walls and roof together before it was decorated with a sprinkling of icing sugar to look like snow.The couplersquos creation attracted plenty of attention on social media, with David and Naomi making two versions of the edible structure.One has been given to Naomirsquos grandparents John and Val Golightly, who attend the church, with a second for her mum and dad Ruth Golightly and Colvin Denholm.David, who works for Alba Trees, has promised, though, that this is not the end of the gingerbread versions of the church.Instead, the -year-old from Umea,  kilometres to the north-east of Swedenrsquos capital city Stockholm, has vowed to make a ldquobigger and better version for next Christmas.Naomi, , said: ldquoDavid was drawing a picture for my grandparents for Christmas of the church, which is nice. As well as that, he decided to try to make the church.ldquoHe said this was just his first attempt and next year will be much better than this!

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-signs-top-rank-deal

Fighter of the Year and won the Word Boxing Super Series in fantastic fashion with his win over Regis Prograis."Hes now linking up with Top Rank and MTK Global, so his sights are solely set on unying the ision and becoming a global star on both sides of the Atlantic.ldquoThis is a momentous partnership for all involved."MTK Global and Top Rank have a recent history of working together with title: dunbars-trial-20mph-speed-limit-set-become-permanent
story: The speed limit on the majority of streets to the north of the railway line was dropped from mph to mph in August .The change in speed limit was to be in place for  months before members of the public were given the chance to have their say on whether it should remain in place or revert back to the previous mph limit.A public consultation ndash both online and through leaflets posted through doors ndash was carried out to gather feedback.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire said the findings of the survey showed that the majority of people were in favour of keeping the reduced speed limit.He told Dunbar Community Council: ldquoThe survey results came back and  per cent of people were in support of it continuing.ldquoHowever, there were views that certain roads, distributor roads, as seen around the town should remain at  miles per hour.ldquoTransportation are reviewing the scheme and looking at roads they feel warrant ato mph. It will only be on major routes in the town but mph will continue because the survey results came back in favour of that.The final say on the scheme is likely to come at a council committee meeting, with a report currently being drawn up.Herbert Coutts, from the townrsquos community council, has been heavily involved in the move to see a reduced speed limit put in place.He said: ldquoI would be interested ndash presumably it is included within the report ndash to hear what the police evidence has been.ldquoThat is a big factor in all this.ldquoThe survey of public opinion is one thing but the police evidence and the results of the tests that were done in the same places where the council had recorded the speed of cars prior to the start of the trial [would be useful].A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the report would look at ious issues, including the public consultation and the possibility of including or removing streets from the mph speed limit. Similarly, it would highlight whether average speeds at ious hot spots had reduced.She added: ldquoIt was certainly noticeable on Summerfield Road that speed had reduced signicantly.

title: Rosemary Goring  Having a cat is like tossing a grenade onto a bird table
story: On a recent trip to the Moray Firth, I heard about a sighting of a grey squirrel near Elgin, which was believed to have smuggled itself in, like Jason Bourne, on the back of a lorry. No big deal, you might think, but in these parts the red squirrel is better protected than the royals at Balmoral. A hit squad was despatched to find and eliminate the intruder, which they did within  hours.The grey squirrel, a th-century import from America, has a terrible reputation, thanks to its impact on its native red cousin. Culling is usually considered the best solution and, for the sake of the red, which is particularly susceptible to disease carried by its relative, I wouldnrsquot argue with that. Less grisly but more final are attempts at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh to alter the DNA of female greys to render them infertile. If that works then theyrsquoll soon disappear forever, hopefully leaving To Let signs encouraging reds to .No such fancul nonsense in the scientic world, of course. An ecologist at Edinburgh Napier University has pointed out the double standards involved in public attitudes. Whereas the grey squirrel has conservationists reaching for guns and traps, another ldquoinvasive alien species ndash the domestic cat ndash is so beloved, there are an estimated  million in the UK.Ecologist Dr Jason Gilchrist, writing on the academic website The Conversation, says: ldquoIt is often argued that killing grey squirrels is justied as they predate bird nests. They do, and so do red squirrels, but there is scant evidence that squirrels have a signicant impact on songbirds. While domestic and feral cats decimate songbird populations, they are unlikely to be targeted for culls any time soon... In terms of the ecological damage they do, the impact of both species is similar: they donrsquot belong here and are having negative effects on wildle.While this doesnrsquot emphasise the potentially irreversible effect of greys on red squirrels, he has a point about predatory cats. They kill about  million wild birds every year. It would be a horrying tallythese were all healthy young things but the RSPB says the majority are either sickly or weak and would soon have expired anyway. Cold comfort for those of us clearing the crime scene where a fat wood pigeon has gasped its last. Nor do I entirely believe it. Watching a black tom motionless as a gatepost beside our chirruping beech hedge, itrsquos easy to see how a healthy robin, fooled into thinking it was a shadow, could be caught unawares.Even the most besotted owners squirm at the trophies dropped at their feet ndash often not entirely dead ndash and while itrsquos good to keep down rodents, disposing of feathered carcasses tucked in your slippers is no fun. I say this as a cat person. So far as Irsquom aware, the only thing my city cat ever caught was a mouse, which I managed to rescue and put back on the street. My cat used to sleep like a Russian fur hat on my pillow, and when she died it was little short of heartbreaking. But now I have a garden, with a hedge that quivers with sparrows and finches, I couldnrsquot possibly replace her. It would be like tossing a live grenade onto the lawn. Itrsquos in catsrsquo nature to kill, and other than keeping them confined indoors, or hanging a bell as loud as Big Ben around their neck, they will inevitably go on carnivorous sprees.Dr Gilchrist is well aware that his comments might outrage the feline-owning community. His aim, he says, is simply ldquoto bring some logic and consistency to the way we treat animals. The problem is, therersquos nothing logical about the love cats inspire.Pointing out the savage heart that beats within every sweetly purring tabby, for instance, makes absolutely no dference to the cooing and clucking around their every move. Ian Fleming knew what he was doing when he placed a cold-eyed white Persian in his villain Blofeldrsquos arms. It was hard to tell which was the more sinister, each, as he implied, being utterly deadly. More recently, the costume designers and make-up artists for the film version of Cats were way off the mark. Turning one of the most alluring and lithe species into a creepy hybrid with long legs, flapping arms and a human body completely misses the essence of the feline kingdom. Whether itrsquos a Siamese or a tortoiseshell, a Bengal or a Manx, elegance is key. Much of the allure lies in their aesthetic appeal and the dignity and hauteur with which they behave. Itrsquos no wonder the Egyptians treated them as Gods. Nor that they were considered an essential accessory for a witchrsquos diabolical work.Whereas squirrels might be impressively athletic and undeniably cute, they cannot compete with the fascination cats hold. This arises in part from their disturbingly dual personality. Unlike dogs ndash what you see is what you get ndash they are mysterious and ungovernable. As they lie on your lap, exquisitely lovely and touchingly affectionate, they make people feel special. Therersquos a sense of pride in being favoured by a sharp-toothed beast with vicious claws that, when it slips out of the window flap at midnight, turns into a merciless killer, and by day treats the garden like ScotRailrsquos buffet trolley.As anyone who dares suggest cats are a nuisance will soon learn, in this country they are all but sacred. When it comes to choosing between the fate of felines or songbirds, itrsquos very simple: two legs good, four legs infinitely better.

title: sturgeon-consider-neer-day-trading-ban
story: As the shop workers union protested outside Holyrood in favour of such a ban, the First Minister said she sympathised and would look at what steps the Government could take.The Christmas Day and New Years Day TradingAct  bans the opening of most large stores - defined as more than  square metres in size - on Christmas Day.It also allows Scottish Ministers to introduce a similar ban for New Yearrsquos Day, but the provision has never been used.:Nicola Sturgeon refutes claims of secret investigation into falling Higher pass rateA recent Usdaw survey of  Scottish retail staff found  per cent thought stores should close on New Yearrsquos Day to give workers more time with friends and family.At First Ministerrsquos Questions, Labour MSP Jackie Baillie raised the Usdaw campaign.She said: ldquoMany retail workers in Scotland had to work on  January instead of spending time with their families.ldquoParliament has already put in place legislation covering Christmas and New Yearrsquos Day trading that would stop large stores from opening, but the New Yearrsquos Day provisions have not been implemented.ldquoWill the First Minister commit to backing Usdawrsquos calls, to consulting on new yearrsquos day trading and to giving shop workers the festive break that they deserve Ms Sturgeon replied: ldquoShop workers deserve a festive break such as the rest of us get the benefit of. I commit to looking very carefully at the Usdaw campaign.ldquoI absolutely understand the motivations that are driving the campaign, and I will consider what further steps the Government can take to address those concerns.ldquoWhen I have had the opportunity to do that, I will be happy to ask the relevant minister to reply in detail to Jackie Baillie.The  law, which exempts restaurants, motorway services and garages, was promoted by the former Labour MSP Karen Whitefield.However after the SNP came to power that year, then SNP Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskill swtly ruled out a New Yearrsquos Day trading ban.The Government was praised by business leaders after it said it was ldquonot prepared to burden them with more unnecessary and unwanted regulations".David Lonsdale, director of the Scottish Retail Consortium, said a ban would be "outdated" and unwelcome.He said: ldquoWhere there is demand from customers and availability of staff then shops ought to continue to be free to choose to open on New Years Daythey so wish."The notion of banning trading on Nersquoer Day is outdated and ill-thought out considering customers can already shop online whenever they choose."It is also unclear why shops have been singled out and not firms in sectors such as hospitality, tourism and leisure. Implementing a trading ban would send out a very poor signal, and would fly in the face of the strenuous efforts being made to revitalise our high streets and to promote Scotland as a visitor destination at New Year.

title: mark-smith-snp-broken-one-basic-rules-politics---paid-off
story: Question One: How do you feel about paying more tax to fund public services  A Supportive or B Not supportive.Question Two: What is your tax residency status  A Scottish or B Rest of the UK Question Three : Do you think Scotland should be independent  A Yes or B No.Irsquom asking these three questions now because theyrsquove been interacting in quite an interesting way lately. The question about tax residency, for example, will have come upyoursquove been filling in a tax . The issue of paying more taxes has also been raised by the recent National Audit Office report showing that, because of changes introduced by the Scottish Government, Scots paid almost poundm more in income tax in   than the year before.:Scots estimated to have paid poundm more in income tax following SNP tax changesIt would seem, from what Irsquove seen, that voters in the second group who say theyrsquore happy to pay extra tax outnumber those who are unhappy, and this is curious for two reasons. First, it appears to defy one of the basic rules of British politics, but it also obeys another rule of Scottish politics that runs much deeper.The basic rule of British politics says this: do not raise taxes because voters wonrsquot like it. More specically, the rule suggests voters will say they donrsquot mind paying more tax for better services but vote for parties that lower taxes. Itrsquos the dference between the publicity of opinion and the secrecy of the ballot - when things are secret, people can do what they believe, not what they think they should believe.The thing is, though, political rules arenrsquot quite as simple as that. On the face of it, the rule works: Margaret Thatcherrsquos governments, for example, reduced income tax and won three elections, and Tony Blairrsquos governments did pretty much the same: they cut income tax further and kept on winning.However, the details reveal something a bit more subtle. For a start, the Tories arenrsquot as tax-cutting as they say they are ndash the Thatcher governments cut income tax but also dramatically raised VAT. Isolating tax as an issue also fails to understand what truly motivates voters. There will be some who think excessively cutting tax will make public services worse and vote accordingly, but more important is how voters prioritise issues in their heads.It works like this: tax rates, corruption, inefficiency, immorality ndash all of these matter to voters but none of them matter as much as the issue that, deep down, they really care about. It explains why Boris Johnson does well despite all the questions over his record . And it explains why the SNP continue to do well despite all the questions over theirs .What this means in Scotland is the SNP can appear to break the tax rule and still do well because some voters care more about independence than taxes. It also means that the risk of higher costs or economic damage has no effect on some voters ndash witness the reaction of some to the economic risks of independence. They. Donrsquot. Care.The SNPrsquos defence to all of this is that the greater tax burden is ldquoprogressive and raises extra revenue for ldquofirst-class public services but both claims are dodgy. First, Scotlandrsquos public services are not first class, but the extra taxes also cannot be progressive when they apply to people earning pound,. Wouldnrsquot it be more progressive to end benefits that can be claimed by the well-off  And what about council tax ndash was it progressive to freeze it, thereby benefitting affluent households more than poorer ones while also forcing councils to cut services The point is that, even though the Donrsquot-Raise-Tax rule is still relevant, here in Scotland the deeper magic of independence matters more it also means public services can get worse and taxes can get higher and the SNP continues to do well. Maybe the new rule for politicians in Scotland should be: think about independence first. But maybe therersquos another lesson too: often itrsquos the politicians who break the rules that do best in the end.

title: truly-radical-royals-harry-meghan-ditch-duke-duchess
story: Not  hours after Meghan Markle and her husband made the unexpected announcement they are to demote themselves from senior to minor royals - seemingly without running it past the boss of the firm first - Madame Tussauds removed the couples waxworks from its royal family display.If only the real le redundancy process the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have applied for could go so smoothly and easily.Rather - strap in - were in for several months of claim and counter claim, insider sources and speculation about the motives of Harry, formerly known as Prince.Despite the collective clutched pearls, its not as though this latest chapter in the royal soap opera wasnt well foreshadowed.Harry did not marry some pliable ingenue. He married a grown woman, a self-made millionaire who had oodles of le experience, had forged her own successful career, who had very set ideas, interests and moral codes and who clearly saw the instant and vast fame of being part of the British Royal family as a means to promote her philanthropic and charitable ideals.Not everyone sees this as a virtue. Confident, refreshing, ambitious Meghan. Pushy, bossy, bitchy Meghan.From day one she has refused to capitulate to the expected mores of a member of the House of Windsor. From going bare-legged at official events to declining the title of Prince for her son from continuing to behave like a typical young American woman with transatlantic baby showers to insisting on the title of Ms and not Miss for herself.Every perceived dference - some say faux pas, some say reasonable modern behaviour - has been noted, recorded and scrutinised.Harry and Meghan were never going to tow the line.Some would say the foreshadowing began  years ago with the abdication of Edward VIII, whose love affair with an American orceacutee is the reason Harry now finds himself in a predicament with his.Thanks to the chain reaction sparked by Edward and Wallis Simpson, Harry is now wrangling with his position within the royal family and without.This is part of the problem. There has been an utter reluctance to meet Meghan Markle on her own terms.She is either compared to Wallis Simpson and found too similar, or compared to Kate Middleton and found to be too dferent.While the Duchess of Cambridge has made herself blandly likeable and upstanding - an inoffensively perfect consort-in-waiting - Meghan would never have been able to do this.Prince Williams we was plagued for being middle class and having an air hostess for a mother. But she is from a good family, received a good education and has blended in seamlessly to aristocratic le.Meghans perceived flaws are insurmountable. She cannot erase her previous marriage from her record. She cannot stop being American.Instead of praising her moral consistency - such as during the rumours of her asking Prince Harry not to go hunting at Sandringham - she was scorned as a scheming nag trying to turn our Harry against us.Prince Harry, goes the narrative, has been altered against his will by this conniving vixen. Much has been made of a what a rambunctious young fellow the Prince used to be. It really shows how deeply held the disdain for Meghan that we preferred Harry in his Las Vegas, photographer-punching, Nazi costume wearing days.Would Britain really rather its sixth in line to the throne was gadding to parties in an SS unorm than spending some time in Canada over Christmas Most crucially, Ms Markle cannot make herself less black. While Britain balks at the notion it might be a bit racist, lets try and be honest enough to acknowledge the racist undertones to the criticism of Meghan.Prince Harry, too, has been consistent and vocal. He has asked the press nicely to back off and he has threatened the press to back off. The press did not back off and now, he likely feels, theyve got what they deserved.It is highly doubtful this will wash well with the tabloids.The Harry and Meghan romance has shown up the UKs racism, classism and the uniquely dysal relationship it has with the royal family where the country feels it has ownership because we pay for their upkeep.They get fame, fortune and outrageous privilege and we get to feel like were in control. Now the couple has violated the sacred deal.Its very dficult to emphasise with their position. "Itrsquos not enough just to survive something, right ," Meghan said in her Africa interview last year. "Thatrsquos not the point of le. Yoursquove got to thrive, yoursquove got to feel happy."How, it is nigh-on impossible to imagine, can you feel in survival mode with a doting husband, beautul baby, unlimited privilege and absolute luxury.Yet this is how Harrys we feels and their decision to publish on Wednesday evening or be damned speaks to an interesting utter lack of trust in the Palace.They want to earn their own living using their royal brand for commercial gain - freeing Meghan up to play herself in the Crown, perhaps - yet still live in Crown Estate property and take money from the Duchy of Cornwall.Other royal couples before them have given it a try - the Countess of Wessex tried and failed to keep up her PR work with royal duties - so they have a template for what not to do.Having a foot in each camp seems an attempt to have all the upsides and no downs. Perhaps its designed to be a compromise - a compromise between themselves or a compromise between them and us - but its a poor deal.The royal family is rightly paring back to become a more modern institution in a world that does not have automatic deference to its mere existence.After the initial shock of their announcement, there would be more understandingthe Sussexes went it alone. They should drop their titles, cut their royal income and be truly independent. Royal fans will love them regardless and anti-monarchists can at least have respect for their independence.As it is, they look selfish. Not modern or daring, just making a slight sht from the palace to a gilded halfway house of hypocrisy.

title: doubt-cast-savers-260m-gain-bank-regulator-interest-rate-intervention
story: The proposed new rules also mean each lender will be banned from quietly cutting interest rates on the accounts - as new data shows Scottish banks are among the stingiest.But experts have questioned whether the new rules proposed by the Financial Conduct Authority will mean consumers would gain an extra poundm from higher interest payments a year - warning that banks would find ways to claw back any losses in other ways.The Herald can reveal that the FCA estimate that the total one-off costs of its intervention would be poundm, with an annual ongoing cost of poundm.Experts say the only way consumers can gain isthey shop around for the best rates and swap banks - but analysis suggests people have been historically reluctant to do so.The reforms by the Financial Conduct Authority would still allow banks to offer introductory interest rates to bring in new customers for a year, but would then have to set a single easy access rateacross all their savings accounts and easy-access cash Isas, ensuring loyal customers do not lose out through lower rates. The proposals also require banks to publish details every six months on the SEARs they offer which should make comparisons easier.The FCA says that the new rules would make it easier for longstanding customers to see whether their existing account gives them a good interest rate because their bank will not have one set interest rate.The rules, which will now go out for consultation, are meant to boost transparency and competition across the easy-access savings market, which has been accused of taking advantage of customers unwillingness to switch."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Financial Conduct Authority video on proposals to help customers get better rates for cash savings","description": "Financial Conduct Authority video on proposals to help customers get better rates for cash savings","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media aNQvKtg poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests aNQvKtg.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The FCA video promoting its intervention.Easy access accounts typically let you pay money in and withdraw it when you want without being penalised.With over , savings accounts available in the UK and around  that are easy access, only a handful offer interest rates that beat the inflation rate which was at .% year-on-year in November.Around  million people hold such accounts in the UK but many longstanding customers receive low rates of interest and therefore miniscule s for their savings.The typical easy access account interest rate has dropped to its lowest point since . The average grossis at .%, down from .% a year ago and is the lowest since September  when it was .%, based on a deposit of pound,, according to one analysis.Analysis from comparison site Moneyfacts shows that the Bank of Scotland Access Saveraccount is among the stingiest in the UK in terms of easy access interest rates offering just .%. The account stays at .% for a year before turning into an instant access savings account, earning .% interest.The best interest deals were .% offered by the Gatehouse Bank and .% given by the Yorkshire Building Society, Cha Building Society, Buckinghamshire Building Society and Ford Money.Clydesdale and RBS offer .% on balances up to pound,.There are concerns that banks will not necessarily offer better interest rates across the board under the new regime.New analysis this month by independent banking experts Savings Champion revealed that even though the base rate has remained level at .% since August , there have been over  rate cuts to existing savings accounts in  alone... and just  rate increases.Anna Bowes, co-founder of Savings Champion said that how consumers would ultimately gain remained "a bit of a headscratcher"."If the banks decide they dont have to increase their easy access savings rate, then it hasnt worked," she said. "If they have been forced to pay higher rates of interest to older customers, does that mean they wont be as generous where "They are already paying rubbish rates, andthe banks are forced to do a SEAR, they will just put a low one in. But the FCA may be hoping this will change the mindset of the banks."The bottom line is that savers have to move their money andthey dont then it is all a pointless exercise. There is so much more that needs to be considered other than having one interest rate."If people do suddenly become engage in switching accounts, then it would be a dferent story. But that is the big ."Rachel Springall, finance expert at Moneyfacts, said it was dficult to tell how attractive interest rates will be and advised consumers to shop around."Transparency does not always provide consumers with a better deal and providers would need to work out whether they would have to increase rates for lending to accommodate a rise in paying out interest on savings," she said."Providers are unlikely to offer generous interest rates right now with the current economic and political climate, so they could even be cutting rates to deter investors so that they donrsquot become too cash flushed."The FCA defended its analysis on the consumer gain, saying it was based on their assumption that banks will provide a higher overall interest on easy access savings balances, "as price-sensitive consumers are pooled with less sensitive ones".And it said it has considered that one of the "unintended" consequences of their move may be that banks will try to recoup any increase in costs by raising the cost of their products to consumers."We recognise that firms would continue to manage their net interest margin to earn a , but consider that alongside this they need to have regard to the fair treatment of their longstanding customers," said the FCA."We also expect the overall impact of this intervention to firms to be low compared to total balances held, and any such passing on of costs to be low as a result. We have not seen evidence that competition and effects in the cash savings market have a material impact on other banking products."

title: queen-demands-workable-solution-harry-meghans-future-within-days
story: A Buckingham Palace source said the senior royals have asked aides to work ldquoat pace with governments and The Sussex Household and an outcome was expected to take ldquodays, not weeks.It comes after Harry and Meghan released a bombshell statement on Wednesday saying they would be ldquostepping back as senior royals."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Harry and Meghan step back from royal family: what next ","description": "Harry and Meghan step back from royal family: what next ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media QtgI poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests QtgI.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The Queen and other members of the family were said to be left ldquohurt by Harry and Meghanrsquos decision to issue a personal statement, which outlined their future lives as financially independent royals who will ide their time between the UK and North America.:Harry and Meghan refuse to give up lavish lestyleThe PA news agency understands the royal family will talk to multiple governments which suggests US and Canadian officials may be involved.Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Meghan confirmed she has ed to Canada, where eight-month-old son Archie is said to have stayed with his nanny when his parents flew back to London.A spokeswoman for the duchess said: ldquoI can confirm she is in Canada.It is understood Meghan was always due toto Canada after a brieftrip to the UK. A source told the PA news agency ldquoshe came back to attend some meetings and then went back.The Duke of Cambridge is due to be in Yorkshire for a number of appearances next Wednesday, alongside the Duchess of Cambridge.Meanwhile, Harry is not expected to be seen in public again until next Thursday, when he will do the draw for the Rugby League World Cup in .Given the Queenrsquos timetable of ldquodays it is likely they will want any talks concluded before the Prince of Wales travels to Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories at the end of the month, to mark the th anniversary of the liberation of the former Nazi concentration camp, Auschwitz-Birkenau.It appears the head of state tried to forestall any announcements after her grandson asked to meet at her private Sandringham estate, the Evening Standard newspaper reported, only to be ldquoignored by the couple.The latest developments reveal the isions within the heart of the British monarchy which has already been rocked by the Duke of Yorkrsquos disastrous television interview about his relationship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.:Harry and Meghan to step back as senior royalsHarry and Meghan went ahead and released their personal statement on Wednesday evening which was a ldquobolt from the blue for Buckingham Palace, sources told PA.The statement ndash and a new official Sussexroyal website ndash have thrown up important questions about funding for the couplersquos round-the-clock security, media access to their royal events and how they will pay for their future lestyles.The Duke and Duchess, who have only recently ed from a six-week stay in Canada with eight-month-old son Archie, said in their statement: ldquoAfter many months of reflection and internal discussions, we have chosen to make a transition this year in starting to carve out a progressive new role within this institution.ldquoWe intend to step back as lsquoseniorrsquo members of the royal family and work to become financially independent, while continuing to fully support Her Majesty the Queen.Meghan received a public boost from her close friend Jessica Mulroney, a Canadian stylist and TV star, who posted a quote attributed to Gina Carey, which said: ldquoA strong woman looks a challenge in the eye and gives it a wink.But a series of commentators have strongly criticised their decision with public relations and crisis consultant Mark Borkowski saying about the Sussexes ldquoIt does feel like a royal couple in exile.It is already known the Queen, Prince of Wales and other senior royals were not consulted about the content of the couplersquos statement or knew it was to be issued.But the Standard said Charles and the Duke of Cambridge only received it  minutes before it was released.Over the festive period the newspaper stated Charles told his son to come up with a thought out plan for his wish to spend more time in Canada and America, and when he put forward a draft proposal was told time was needed to consider its implications, particularly funding.The Queen agreed to Harryrsquos request to meet when he ed from Canada but the duke was told his grandmother would not discuss his proposals before he had talked them through with his father.Despite the request not to make any announcements the Sussexes published their statement.Buckingham Palace would not comment on the latest developments in the Harry and Meghan saga, but it is likely royal aides are organising the dukersquos showdown meeting with his father and the Queen.The Sussexes have outlined their future plans in their statement and it will be for royal household staff and aides to work together to make them a reality.

title: radical-plans-edinburgh-set-tram-extension-car-free-city-centre
story: Council leaders have unveiled blueprints for ldquoiconic streets to be ldquoprogressively pedestrianised over the next decade, with George Street to be shut to vehicles by .Proposals to be put out for consultation also float the idea of a congestion charge " necessary", but city chiefs stressed there were no plans to implement this.Meanwhile, "seamless ticketing" will allow passengers to easily move between buses, trams and other modes of transport.Parking controls will also be extended "for the benefit of residents", freeing up space from commuter parking.Edinburgh is the fastest growing city in Scotland, while the cost of traffic congestion to the local economy is estimated at pound million a year.Adam McVey, the leader of Edinburgh Council, said: ldquoWersquore already making great strides towards reducing carbon emissions in Edinburgh but,we are to achieve our  target, now is the time to be even bolder and more ambitious."The City Mobility Plan offers a radical, ten-year plan to transform transport in the capital, achieving the kind of change we need by expanding use of bus, tram, rail, walking and cycling to provide the best quality of le for everyone.ldquoWhatrsquos crucial to any strategy, however, is buy-in of our residents and those who travel into the capital to work and visit."Everyone needs to play their part and I look forward to engaging with the public as we progress a finalised City Mobility Plan, alongside the development of the City Plan .Council leaders drew inspiration from cities such as Copenhagen, Paris, Sydneyand Barcelona when drawing up their plans,as well as thosecloser to home such as Manchester and London.Their strategy document says funding theproposals "will be challenging, requir[ing]signicant capital investment, business transformation, and changing revenue streams."They plan new bus and tram systems by , by which point they hopeair pollution levels will have been signicantly reduced due to city centre and city-wide low emission zones.By , the "mass transit network", including new tram lines, will have been extended west to Newbridge and will have been developed to connect the waterfront in the north to the Royal Infirmary in the south and beyond.The document says the city centre "will be largely car-free" in a decades time, while a "comprehensive new bus route network will be in place, with hubs at gateways to the city centre, and our iconic streets will be progressively pedestrianised"."Elsewhere pavements widths will have been signicantly widened with obstacles removed," it adds.Council chiefs say they plan to "expand the tram mass rapid transport network to the north and south of the city as well as to Newhaven and explore the potential to extend routes to the west of the city and into Fe, West, Mid and East Lothian".Meanwhile, a congestion charge could be considered "in the course of updates to [the] council on the level of success of the overall strategy and the impact of measures introduced over the early years of it".The paper adds: "Road user charging is an effective way of reducing the number of cars in a city by encouraging drivers to switch to public transport, walking and cycling, and providing a funding to support the development of alternative mobility options."If they are approved by councillors, an eight-week public consultation on the draft plans will begin in February.Edinburgh wants to reduce carbon emissions arising from road transport to zero by .In a foreword to thenew strategy document, Councillor Lesley Macinnes, Edinburghrsquos transport convener, said: ldquoOver the past ten years Edinburgh has made signicant progress. But now is the time for bolder, more transformational action.ldquoMaking a positive dference to peoplersquos lives in a fast changing environment requires ambition, courage, focus and a change of pace in delivery.ldquoWe cannot spend another twenty years building a single tram line, when we need to develop a truly integrated public transport network, including additional tram lines, in the next ten years.Edinburgh is already pushing ahead with plans for low emission zones and a new workplace parking tax.John Lauder, deputy chief executive of the walking and cycling charity Sustrans,said the proposals were "the start of an exciting conversation for residents about how they want to get around the city".He said: "This is a topic that is high on the agenda of everyone who lives, works and visits the city, but it is also of importance across other Scottish cities.ldquoWe are pleased that this ambitious and long-term plan not only looks at the city centre, but the suburbs too and addresses how we travel in and out of the capital on direct, fast, convenient routes by walking, cycling and public transport.ldquoThis is vitalEdinburgh is to tackle congestion, accommodate the growth of the city and jobs and meet its laudable target of becoming carbon neutral by .ldquoWe look forward to taking part in the consultation and urge everyone to have their say on Edinburghrsquos plans.Stuart Hay, director of walking charity Living Streets Scotland, said: ldquoItrsquos vital that Edinburgh matches the efforts of European capitals, including Paris, Brussels and Oslo which have taken bold measures to prioritise pedestrians instead of traffic."A largely car-free city centre by  is essentialEdinburgh is to tackle air pollution, congestion and health issues associated with inactivity."

title: wolf-moon-2020-lunar-eclipse-set-delight-skygazers
story: Weather permitting, those gazing up at the skies will witness a penumbral lunar eclipse when the moon passes through the earthrsquos shadow,The phenomenon, which will begin at pm and is expected to end at around pm, will see the moon move into Earthrsquos penumbra, or outer shadow, causing the earthrsquos natural satellite to look darker than normal.:Moon spell: humanityrsquos love affair with our silver satelliteBonnie Diamond, a spokesperson for the Met Office, said ldquolovely clear skies are expected for south-east England in the evening.But she added skies may be cloudier in the western parts of the country, with heavy rain expected across northern Ireland and Scotland in the late afternoon.In January, the full moon is sometimes labelled a ldquowolf moon, an unusual celestial label which seems to have stuck.Ed Bloomer, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said: ldquoThe first full moon of  is today, and here in the UK we should be able to see it nice and clearly.ldquoIt will be rising in the east as the sun sets in the west, and wersquoll be able to observe it throughout the night.But those expecting the moon to turn red, a phenomenon dubbed the blood moon, will be disappointed.Mr Bloomer added: ldquoWe wonrsquot see the same dramatic dimming and reddening visible during a total lunar eclipse.ldquoUnfortunately, we wonrsquot get one of those until , though there are another three penumbral eclipses to look forward to in .The next full moon will occur on February , which is also known as snow moon.

title: edinburgh-adventurer-becomes-youngest-woman-ski-solo-south-pole
story: Mollie Hughes started her world record attempt on November , departing from Hercules Inlet in Western Antarctica.The -year-old skied eastwards for  miles and arrived at the South Pole on Friday at .am local time.:Crew attempts first row to AntarcticaldquoItrsquos a surreal feeling, I canrsquot quite believe Irsquove done it, she said.ldquoI knew it would be hard but this has been an exceptionally tough experience, especially in the first two weeks when I was struggling through the whiteout for over a week and incredibly strong winds.ldquoThat really tested my resilience, especially as I was all alone, but I managed to get through it and carry on.ldquoI feel really fortunate not to have experienced any major disasters knowing what can happen in these challenging conditions.The mountaineer, who grew up in Devon, said spending Christmas on her own was dficult.ldquoChristmas Day away from my girlfriend and family was hard, too, as was my Spoty music service needing rebooted after  days, which obviously wasnrsquot possible, she said.After . days of skiing I am standing at the Geographic South Pole as the youngest woman EVER to ski solo from the coast of Antarctica to the Pole! | Find me with inReach#https:t.co bObamHtJfoldquoNow Irsquom looking forward to my first shower and proper food in almost two months before I head home to see everyone and share my story.Ms Hughes, who in  became the youngest person to have successfully climbed both the north and south sides of Mount Everest, endured brutal conditions at the start of her latest challenge.At one point she entered complete whiteout conditions for eight days, which she described as ldquolike being inside a ping-pong ball.With no visibility, she had to navigate by compass through -knot winds, which took temperatures down to minus C.Having initially hoped to reach the South Pole by New Yearrsquos Day, her quest was almost derailed by severe weather in the first two weeks, with Ms Hughes facing headwinds of more than  knots, temperatures of minus C and a whiteout for eight days in a row.During the expedition, she pulled a kg sled ndash which she named Boudicca ndash and skied alone for between  and  hours a day.Conditions become so severe she was confined to her tent for stretches, meaning she could not complete her original goal of becoming the youngest person to ski solo and unsupported to the South Pole.The adventurer was given some surprise respite on Christmas Day when she discovered logistics company ALE had hidden secret gts in her food stores, meaning she could feast on pad thai, chocolate cake, fresh bread rolls, grapes, kiwi and nectarine for Christmas dinner.Her girlfriend Tegan sent not only Ms Hughesrsquos favourite sweets ndash Revels ndash but also her own top treat of chocolate-covered pretzels as well as a bar of honeycomb chocolate with a picture of Edinburgh on the front.Ms Hughes is now recuperating at a camp at the South Pole before flying on to Punta Arenas in southern Chile.After a few daysrsquo rest there, she is expected to arrive back in her home city of Edinburgh on January .She funded her expedition by raising pound, from sponsors and crowdfunding, and used the trek as a way to raise money for Cancer Research UK.Michelle Mitchell, chief executive of the charity, said she was in awe of the adventurerrsquos ldquodetermination and resilience.:Swimmer looks for partners to help him in Antarctic challengeShe added: ldquoIrsquod also like to thank Mollie for using the trek as an opportunity to raise vital funds to beat cancer, a disease that affects so many.ldquoWe receive no government funding and itrsquos thanks to people like Mollie that wersquore able to continue to fund world leading research.ldquoWe hope others will feel inspired by Molliersquos effort and support our lesaving work.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: NEWS, finally, from the long-lost Citizens Assembly of Scotland, the poundmillion talking shop completely overshadowed by Brexit and the general election last year. The body recently published hundreds of membersrsquo ideas for ldquothe Scotland we are seeking to build. We suspect many will please the SNP ministers behind it, but not all. Alongside ldquobe free of nuclear weapons and ldquobe free of poverty, there was also an aspiration for the country to ldquobe free of Nicola Sturgeon.RainmakersONLY the optimists of All Under One Banner could have had the brainwave to stage a march and rally in the depth of a Scottish winter. In a triumph of hope over meteorology, they chose today, in famously clement Glasgow, for their first Indyref outing of , predicting a record , soggy souls would attend. After the inevitable weather warnings, it has now been cut back to just a march and no rally. Perhaps it should be rebranded All Under One Umbrella.Jack the FlopperMUCH toe-curling at the first Scottish Questions of the year at Westminster as Tweedy Scottish Secretary Alister Jack stumbled and stuttered through a series of schoolboy errors. Besides mangling the Sewel convention, he also informed MPs: ldquoThe majority of Scots voted to Remain, to, the majority of votes voted, sorry, to Leave in , to leave the European Union. Feel enlightened  No wonder hersquos considered lsquoreshuffle readyrsquo, with Douglas Ross waiting in the wings.Nat-a-tat-tatNOW an MP, former SNP Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskill remains an unrivalled thorn in his partyrsquos side, casually writing off Indyref anytime soon at the New Year. Did he inspire fellow Nat MP John Nicolson, we wonder  The latter, who lovingly restored a listed building in London, has been fuming on Twitter about one being demolished in Glasgow. ldquoWhat a shameful decision by the Glasgow SNP Council. Embarrassing, he wrote on Twitter, sparking a public row with a senior SNP councillor. Watch your crown, Kenny.Double dateALSO in the Commons, MPs held elections for the three deputy speakers this week. The list of candidatesrsquo sponsors raised some eyebrows. SNP MP Martyn Day backed uber-Tory Sir David Amess, while Nats Stewart McDonald and Martin Docherty-Hughes backed Tory Dame Eleanor Laing. But not a patch on SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC, who sponsored both Tory Nigel Evans on the government side and Labourrsquos Dame Rosie Winterton from the opposition. A case of having your cherry cake and eating it, perhaps In the blue cornerFAREWELL to Holyroodrsquos top spindoctors. Asto prove their partiesrsquo mutual dependence, SNP press boss Fergus Mutch and Tory strategy smoothie Eddie Barnes announced their exits on the same day. It led to some confusion. One newspaper tweeted a picture of Nat Fergus under the headline ldquoA key player in the Scottish Toriesrsquo rise under Ruth Davidson is to depart. His colleagues joked there may be some truth to that...
